title: A boy walks at a speed of 4 kmph how much time does he walk a distance of 20 km? - Quora

response.answer_text: A ‘boy’ ? Lets say 10 years old. (the average you can call ‘boy’) You say distance.. You mean point A to point B? 20km.. at 4 kph walking speed… Well, if he was REALLY worried about being late for something at outset that would be 5 hours walking plus 2 x 15 min breaks,(few 10yr olds could walk that long without a rest-short legs) + 1 hour 20 minutes totally distracted aimlessly by something ‘COOL’, like a rabbit path into the bushes,deer track etc, 15 minutes having a dump and picking nose in bushes, so probably about 7 hours 10 minutes and I doubt he could tell you why he was late. WITHOUT any urgency at outset, arrival time would be only slightly longer.. (An ‘urgent’ start would wear off at the first distraction,and realisation of broken deadline would sap the worry- Late is Late : whats another day grounded?) Boys, eh? ;#} Pretend to be Annoyed, its not his fault really.

A boy walks at a speed of 4km/hr. How much time does he take to walk a distance of 20km? Answer 6.5 hours. Along that stretch of 20km the boy has two stops. The first is to stop at his Aunt’s house to pick up some money. But he has to wait 1/2 hour for his Aunt to stop gossiping on the phone so he can ask for the money. The other stop is at the grocery store, but he has trouble finding the things his mother told him to get, so that adds an hour. Maybe subtraction will be easier for you than division :-P

speed of boy=4km/h time aken to cover distance of 20 km= s=d/t time=distance/speed time=20/4 =5 hr. the object will take 5 hr to cover the given distance. for more typical physics question click on the given link get some related question

You might find it easier if you use the correct unit abbreviation. I think you mean a speed of 4 km/h. That way it’s more obvious how to approach your homework. Clue: for a girl it would be approximately 0.00057 year.
That’s a tough one. You’re gonna have to bring in the astro-physicists, NASA engineers, and polymaths to put their heads together.
